VRouskNrzjJr2j8KlgseuQ.text: Yum! Cheap food, big portions, quick service.Chop Chop is nothing pretentious at all; it really is a minimalist Asian canteen. But it works well -- very well trafficked indeed, and good, tasty food at a very reasonable price. Its location very close to Kings Cross also makes it useful for grabbing a bite after a long train journey.Not a destination restaurant by any means. But if you want to eat something Chinese, filling and tasty in 30 minutes flat, it's a good place to go!

Ms45IO4JkzvU_cn3YGVsOA.text: Very Yummy!After ordering some takeout fried rice and chicken chowmein I went across the street for some goodies at the newsstand and came back to find the food ready despite the place being packed.The food was very cheap and delicious. :)

LKpKbAtlE6Q9gq_lOIXqSQ.text: Mediocre food. Very cheap.Service was pretty garbage: when the table next to us asked the waitress for some salt, she reached over and grabbed it from our table without so much as an "excuse me" or "are you done with this?" Listening to the way the waitress addressed these same girls... so rude.I'm from California, and this place doesn't even come close. These noodle soups were bland and boring- I hate adding soy sauce to soups, but had to do so here.The bbq pork was very fatty and not even the right color! (blasphemous) It also tasted a little weird - like it was old. ICKI suppose I would give them another try, but only if I were really really hungry and not craving noodle soup.

bQmxyk6r5Vui73-fNftdAg.text: My girlfriend insisted we check this place out after we returned from Italy. I was promised good Asian food for a very low price and I was not disappointed in the slightest sense. The food here is on par with many of the Asian restuarants in the US which is a huge accomplishment in itself, but it comes at a pricepoint that will completely undercut any of its competitors! If you want a filling meal for a great price, there's not much more you can ask for than Chop Chop Noodle Bar, located conveniently across King's Cross. P.S. Personally I'm curious what their profit margins are (I imagine it to be paper-thin), but as a customer I can't complain at all.

_E4vupjuTNEs8YSMV2cmGw.text: I was dreaming of a big bowl of Asian-style noodle soup (in reality I wanted Pho) and imagined a lovely bowl of piping hot broth with big chunks of shredded chicken, bean sprouts, basil leaves, jalapenos and vermicelli noodles.  I was super-disappointed to get home and find broth, noodles and a fried chicken cutlet.  No greenery to be found :( BIG diasppointment.  Oh, and there was some big delay with the kitchen--I didn't understand it--maybe a shift change?  15 minutes for my lame soup.

x-uDWhxpE3yI_PSyB6Sb5Q.text: THis is my usual stop when I'm getting the train from London back home to Scarborough. Great and easy food. And the price is first class

xjknSJETwQLsQY6YMj24CQ.text: I take it back Chop Chop. You've let me down one too many times. Last time we went my boyfriend's Laksa tasted of dishwater, my noodles were cold and my meat tasted really old. Also the hot and sour soup is horrible. Worth making the extra trek to Chinatown, or just paying a few pounds extra somewhere else.

Fb6Ezc5ynnRMZ5VvtKkx-w.text: You get what you pay for, effectively: big portions, not the best quality around, but as the previous Qyper says, far better than any of the nearby assortment of kebab houses and fish and chip shops. I've been there a couple of times now and far prefer the fish and noodle dishes to anything involving duck (which seemed pretty bone-filled and a bit dry). Cheap and cheerful.

m7gzpa26_nRmNI0exw5QxQ.text: Chop Chop as someone trying to make you in a hurry would say. Quick this place is too. Not so quick that food is ready before you order, do allow 10 minutes whether you are eating in or getting takeaway. In fact I could not reccommend this place enough if you have 20 minutes or more before your train leaves Kings Cross station. You might stick out the carriage of the Edinburgh train with your Black Bean Chicken and rice, but trust me you will thank me for the tip to come here. It is cheap. You get what you pay for so expect big portions but not the highest quality of food. However, King's Cross is full of poor quality food so this is a good choice. All mains are under a fiver and they take credit and debit cards over five pounds. There is a good range of noodle, soup and rice dishes with seafood, chicken, beef, pork or duck for main course and starters are reflective of Thai, Chinese or Korean food. Don't forget to get a healthy juice with your mealpersonally I love the carrot juice along with a main and starter which you can eat in and leave a 15% tip for £9 in total.

wBzI0qLYuifN1LI2CQDV0Q.text: my fabulous friend and i, several years ago, dressed up like fucking crazy ass pirate hookers and enjoyed a delicious meal of noodles here. not only did they serve us, they didn't judge us. i miss you, chop chop. i miss visiting you 3-4 times a week to get my mediocre chow mein fix.  i grew up in northern california, eating chinese food ALL the damn time, and if you hadn't been around, i would have probably died of starvation during my year abroad.

i2QKqUxPkmlBwn99IjtPlA.text: Chop chop noodle shop was delish! I am an American living in Bloomsbury and was craving Chinese food so I thought I'd give it a shoot. We had to wait for a few minutes to get a table for 5 but that was perfectly fine. We ordered springrolls (very good, not too greasy), dumpings (steamed), beef in black bean sauce w/ flat noodles (very tasty), fried seafood rice (which was really just  seafood in a white sauce with white rice that wasn't fried), barbecued pork with flat noodles (the sauce was little too sweet for anyone's taste at the table), and sweet and sour chicken with lo mein noddles (which was very tasty). Overall chop chop was a steal for only 24 pounds with plenty of leftovers for everyone to take away, I will be going back very soon.

XflbJlI5fngr4WVlDJpDYQ.text: Ugh!  What is it with London and Chinese food?This place was cheap and the service was fast, but the food was inedible.  My husband's sweet and sour chicken with rice was fluorescent red and terrifying...  I ordered a noodle dish with vegetables that was really beyond description.  So sad.  We were really looking forward to dinner but would up eating tea and toast at home.We won't be back.

ZFTjqUgLbcQkvpRN2L0bLA.text: Cheap, big portions of food ranging from mediocre to disgusting.  I gave this place three tries but will not go back if I can avoid it.  The first time I picked Malaysian fried rice (I didn't like it), and sweet corn soup (yummy).The next time I was there I tried some flat noodles which had an odd flavor that didn't appeal to me.  Giant portion wasted.On my third visit, I decided to try the sweet and sour chicken fried rice.  The chicken made me gag.Maybe I'm not picking the right dishes.. everyone else seems satisfied but I don't think this place is good at all.  Don't think I'll be giving Chop Chop a fourth chance.  I'd rather pay more and go to Oodle Noodle for Asian foodle done right.

2O2-YQaQOpFB0YGRVcC09g.text: Because I was a poor, stingy American student due to the dollar to pound exchange rate at the time, I went here wayyyy too often when I was studying abroad in London. It was pretty much the only place around where I could get my Chinese food fix, and it was ridiculously cheap. The food itself wasn't too amazing, but the prices and portions easily made it the best deal around.

9EciPMZl-BpfYUDbTxgiIA.text: Fast service, good and reasonably priced food. Also very conviniently located near king's cross

vzGaDQMvl5Wz9A9GE5Zfiw.text: It's greasy, it's not the best quality Asian food, particularly if you have been to Asia and/or the US (where I have to say the quality of the Asian food I consider to be better), BUT that being said, the portions are huge and on a coldish day I can't recall much that was more satisfying than taking a walk to the Chop Chop and ordering take out, bringing it back to my lair and devouring it front of my TV or computer.

DDFY3im68WUlNTIRR6qFPA.text: This is simply a much cheaper versions of the famous Wagamamma's. The dishes price at around £3.90 and a small glass of the house white is £1.90 the portions are huge! Located in Central Kings Cross it's quite easy to miss if you're not looking for it. The service is not the friendliest but it is quick and simple ideal if you are in a rush or are more interested in the company present as you won't be continuely hassled. A nice quick and easy meal out that could almost be a take-away.

8Bs6fRzDHeV_U9TPC9GrwQ.text: Chop Chop is great place to go for a cheap Chinese, with branches in West London and near Kings Cross, the food is tasty and arrives quickly.  You can choose to sit in the canteen style dining area or you can also take your food away.  I usually opt for the Malaysian style fried rice and either a glass of freshly squeezed orange juice or a glass of wine. If you are looking for something quick and tasty it's definitely worth a visit.

5_W03CYgme6wpD2fesmOZQ.text: Today, I came in at 1pm and didn't find a free table, so I was seated right next to an older Chinese woman who slurped her noodle soup. After I got my Singapore Laksa (this time not greasy but just right) we both were wondering how packed this place is and agreed that nothing beats homemade Chinese food. We then had an hour conversation about Buddhism, Christianity, America, CCTV, and the fall of the Berlin wall. Quite interesting, and nothing I would have expected when I gave this place a second try. Wait for my second update.

05ldweIMtLLH5T4_-eWs9g.text: For my american friends, this place is like a sit down fancy Panda Express. Great value for the location.  Spring rolls and sweet and sour chicken were delicious. Service was super fast and the portions were generous.

p_WGto9EjYl4cPwHn-jUxA.text: Good cheap and cheerful little Chinese place. £4.70 for (I think) all main meals, all of which were a hearty size. Not as 'authentic' as some of the meals in London China Town, but not bad nonetheless. Plus, located directly opposite from Kings Cross Station - cannot beat it in terms of convenience or price.

WrlpgIQUPCaKgN25khV4xQ.text: Cheeeeap and cheerful.  Came across this while looking for something quick but tasty near Kings Cross station.  What more can you ask for than a giant plate or bowl of noodles for under 5 quid?  I got the khay teow and it was really good.  Not a whole lot of meat but just enough.  Three or four pieces of each fish cake, prawns, and some BBQ pork.  Wasn't too salty like some places and just enough spice. Food came out really quickly. Can't say it has the best service in the world.Don't have such high expectations and you'll enjoy this if you are in the area.

A9a75gbQQ7nb0LmmI60QhQ.text: From the outside, it looks like a place to avoid rather than trying but I suppose you can't always judge a book by its cover.  The place is definitely much bigger than I expected as I didn't expect to see so many tables.  I ordered the Singapore Laksa - Becareful - let it cool off a bit because I nearly burned my tongue about 10x.  It's not bad for what you pay for.  It's definitely a better choice than McDs or want something other than Pret.  I would definitely try it again if I'm in the area but wouldn't go out of my way for it.

LL_5PhSGIA3Gql2fhTKAmw.text: Flavorless and dull. We needed a quick bite before getting a train from Kings X - the service was fast but the highlight of the meal was the beer. The broth in the noodle soup (even after the addition of soy and chilli) struggled to taste of anything at all, the stri fried noodles were oily and lifeless. Never again.

OzFcoBgx5tFa2GGt3IL1Qw.text: I have never in my life wrote a yelp review but I feel like ChopChop deserves it. I studied abroad in London for 5 months, so I was drunk and poor 98% of the time which means eating out, or eating at all, was rare. But once my two best friends, Jamie and Jenny, discovered that with the pocket change we had left over from O'Neill's we could eat happily, I became ChopChop's biggest fan. It has been almost 2 years but every time I'm drunk I think to myself, 'fuck, i wish there was a chop chop in new york city.' (this is probably why i am writing this review)much love ChopChop and all the pimps who work out of the back hallway/kitchen.

mdCB6TEppOH3MhkKqRIqEw.text: The food here is deplorable but so, so cheap. If you have an iron stomach, come here and you could eat till you dropped for about only £5. Stay away from anything that has beef, though. I'm pretty sure it's beef processed into pieces...

9IIc7B-FihpAp7ljeryXBA.text: Love to pop in when we visit our son in London. Value for money it cant be beaten. Sweet n sour chicken with chow mein is delicious.

lFPTdscho_1LgkH95MHJYA.text: Cheap, fast, Chinese Food. When I am in London, this is my go to for a fast meal. Don't expect white glove fine dining. Expect a bunch of younger wait staff and a hot delicious meal that's easy on the wallet.  Hot and Sour soup is legit as are the ribs and the special fried rice. Ask for extra satay pepper for 50p and you'll be fine.

yNPLIjQa_L6a2VinyBwHcw.text: I love cheap Chinese food. It makes me happier than presents at Christmas. Chop Chop dishes out a full menu of all the favourites, sweet n sour chicken, chow mein, curry, the whole she-bang. What makes the menu so exciting is the cheapness. £2.90 for special chow mein, score!The service is your typical 'wham bam thank you mam,' no frills, no fuss, just tell them what you want. The eatery is deceptively large and clean but I was taking my special fried rice to take away. The £2.90 portion is big and surprisingly not greasy. It is super basic with an uninspiring taste, but for the price, it is still good value for money. I will certainly be back to Chop Chop Noodle Bar.

QWb10MsSrRVSDGoisa0bLg.text: Holy cheap deliciousness Batman!  Ok, it's not gourment, but 1.90 for delicious plate of dumplings with vinegar is fine for me.  I felt like I was visiting China all over again (except for we were right across from St. Pancras station).  It's fast, cheap, delicious, and plentiful.  Perfect to get away from activities from the British Library or in transit from St. Pancras.

fTTL8pgF8PvsCHQFzykd7Q.text: Cheap noodle bar. Not the highest quality food but its cheap and across the street from Kings Cross.Plain & Simple.

Oiq-HkMYeMs8iNcFIiJNzA.text: Chop Chop is a cool little place across from Kings Cross Station. The food is completely inexpensive and you can either eat in or take away.The place was pretty busy when we went with people waiting for their take away's and also wanting to be seated. This is completely no frills with the actual restaurant being pretty plain looking from the inside.The food is really great, it's pretty tasty and for about Â£3 to Â£4 you get huge plates of food. The fresh fruit juices are also really delicious.I went with my boyfriend and spent Â£15 on two starters, two huge meals, tea and juice - really value for money. A great place to stop by and grab a quick, friendly bite to eat.

photos.caption: Photo of Chop Chop Noodle Bar - London, United Kingdom

YF8uBSzDI-eidTCxc6A3lQ.text: If you're looking for a place with a great price value and good asian food, this is where you should go whilst in London. I almost wouldn't have gone inside only judging the storefront, but what a mistake that would've been! The portions are quite big and very tasty, quickly served and so far the staff has always been very nice and attentive. When you're around Kings Cross, this is the best place to go to for food!

4QsN3YzMIWAZtm9JvOwyPw.text: This was my late night staple while I was studying in London.  I probably frequented this place at least once a week or maybe twice. Luckily for me, it was only a few blocks away :) Conveniently located across the King's Cross station, this little restaurant is quick, easy, CHEAP (which is hard to come by in London), and pretty tasty.  Might I add, they give you huge portions! The Singapore Laksa was my favorite. Spicy noodles in coconut curry soup - YUM! I was full and had leftovers for the next day! The staff was pretty friendly - I guess since my friends and I became regulars at this place and often stopped by for dine in or takeaway.  CHOP CHOP, I MISS YOU!!

i8C5yTwFeVcFHOvd_xaAlA.text: As other reviewers say - cheap food, large portions, and an enjoyable eating experience. They operate on a DIY ordering system - you mark off on a piece of paper your order, they take it away, and lo! it appears a few minutes later.I go here quite often (my chinese friends from the church next door practically live here) as it's incredibly good value, but they don't mind you hanging around for an hour or two having a leisurely lunch. Very handy for King's Cross station, they do takeaway, but be warned, the queues can be mammoth. It's that good :)

zc9m3Uw9PXHm_atyyqscpA.text: Though they really should have named it Chop Chop Noodle Shop...Located in King's Cross, this place is perfect for very cheap asian food.  I had the sweet and sour chicken with noodles which was less than four pounds and lasted me for lunch and dinner; thats less than four pounds for two meals!!  My only complaint is that the tables are perhaps a bit too close together; as in I learned the entire life story of the guy sitting at the table next to me.  I think we felt uncomfortable not talking because we were that close to each other.  Haha at least he was interesting...

1qXtZFnItBmivFJ71HNO_w.text: Chop Chop is a good place to eat on a budget. Generally speaking, the sauces and seasonings are quite tasty. Besides that, the prawn crackers are a safe bet for a tasty side.However, the meat tastes... not that fresh. At Chop Chop's price point, that's acceptable to me.  It makes for a good meal, but not a great one.

IU078ewP4kN51B7whgmVcw.text: One word: laksa! Omg i could just eat it again! The portions are huge and the prices are tiny. Very fast and so tasty! The laksa is spicy , tasty and enough as a meal. I would say a bestseller there. I recommend as well the duck and rice .

XXhWebGi4yz-v1U5K2261w.text: This restaurant is very busy. The dish is plentiful but there are not a lot of meat. The value for price is OK.

g-f3df1X87gox5n2nWNpfA.text: This is the place where I fell in love with Ramen!!!! I had just arrived in London with a couple of friends, and it was a rainy afternoon. We encountered chop chop noodle bar and went right in. The service is not the best, as the waitress was a little rude. I cannot complain about the food and the prices though. I ordered spicy seafood ramen, and prawn fried rice. The soup was so delicious, and they did not hold back on the seafood. The portions here are huge and you will leave very full and satisfied! Dying to go back to London to have some delicious ramen again!

2EpwdG74HYXuHtA1LX5fKg.text: It's a good choice when you want to grab something warm to eat. They have many kinds of Asian food. The service is ok - the staff often gets the wrong orders. Noodles were a lot and vegetable is great.

photos.caption: Photo of Chop Chop Noodle Bar - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Chop Chop Noodle Bar - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Chop Chop Noodle Bar - London, United Kingdom

vQllFnQf1iFCKiRFLKL6Tw.text: BAD BUSINESS PRACTICE!!. Can't review for food because we didn't get to eat. We sat there waiting to order food. When we noticed the cashier flip the sign from accepting card over £10 to "CASH ONLY". The lady who sat next to us even said that they do this all the time. How can we order since we were planing to order many items and more than £10 for sure since we have not enough cash with us. That's the reason we picked the restaurant that accept the card to begin with. So we were about to leave, she said she can try the card but may not work. Stinks!!

LCyRGAtJ7QXhPf4-7WbH_Q.text: I was expecting good Chinese food like at home but this was very different. Their sweet and sour chicken has a bunch of veggies and the sauce on it, their fried rice isn't fried at all, and their chicken wings come with feathers still on them. Do yourself a favor and skip this place.

vTlzpmIERzKjBPdlm2QiNA.text: Busy and quick, it's a good place to grab some food, and they don't even blink at people rocking up in halloween gear with skates on...Needing some food just before a party, we headed here as on previous occasions and were quickly seated (thankfully as it became busy soon after).It's simple, choose your noodles or rice, fill out of the paper form and get your food delivered a short while later. It may not all arrive at the same time, but you shouldn't be waiting long. The portions are big, the meat may not be plenty, but it is quick, hot and will fill an empty belly. Drinks aren't that cheap, starting at £1.50 for a can of coke, but who can really compare, it's about the same as everywhere else now.Malaysian Ho Fun ordered and delivered, with prawns, fish cake, chicken and pork. It's tasty but not great.Paid up and we were out of there inside of 40 minutes or so.

yheXCcxe0TCMD0dqw3vxig.text: Food is ok - no best but we had worse. really disappointed with service.Big confusion with credit card payment - we ask Few times if we can pay card they said yes and when we want to pay they said now.

hnY8ZDjocMcXuWX2griamA.text: Ok, so changing my review to three stars as it looks like they got rid of the nasty people and now the service is slightly friendlier and even faster than it was before.The food is still tasty, huge portions that will leave you satisfied. And still under £5.If you are looking for a quick, affordable bit around Kings Cross and you like Chinese/Oriental food, this is definitely your sport!

ubh1OXxYWG6iMxoIX3S-jg.text: Right, other than the fact that it gave my friend a stomach ache after the laksa... (not sure if it was a mix with his dessert popsicle...) this easy Kings x place is cheap and fast. A good £6 can satisfy your happy tummy. Gwai dil was alright as well. Rice dishes are humongousssssss. Usually come here for their Laksa. Huge portions, fast service. Cheap and easy. Not exactly the most authentic Asian food out there, but well, them boys ain't gonna know. Oh, and they do take outs.

photos.caption: Photo of Chop Chop Noodle Bar - London, United Kingdom. king prawn in egg sauce
Photo of Chop Chop Noodle Bar - London, United Kingdom. Kway Teow

EIWhfYmQlxwVWy4bdsJ3Yw.text: Chop chop is a chain around London that I had tried before but not for a long time... And nothing has changed. Lots of menu options, very reasonable prices and good big size portions (especially any of the soup based dishes). Plenty of seating and you fill in your own order sheet so as good service as you wanna give yourself. On this most recent - a busy Friday night - the food was served extremely fast and we had choice of seats and there is a fast customer dining experience. Had the beef noodles in black bean sauce - that was spicier than I have ever had previously and the meat wasn't great but thankfully the noodles were good. They also do a nice jasmine tea in a decent sized pot to accompany the meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Chop Chop Noodle Bar - London, United Kingdom. Won ton soup starter the only small portion
Photo of Chop Chop Noodle Bar - London, United Kingdom. Beef noodles and black bean sauce - spicier than expected

YKX0SQLIAfM_cKSums6RMA.text: Situated opposite a very busy King's Cross St Pancras station is a equally busy noodle joint - well, an almost everything joint. Come starving as the portions are huge.. meat to noodles ratio is to be questioned, but at around a £5-iver or less for a main course, you can sure expect the amount of meat used.I went for the fried ho fun with beef and it came fairly quickly. The beef was not chewy or tough, which was a pleasant surprise. The food was steaming hot and the noodle were plenty enough to fill you up.A reasonable bar for the price point at around £3 for a glass of house white/red.I will be back... for a cheap, I'm famished, in a hurry, busy busy King's Cross mood. You get what you pay for, just keep that in mind!

6WItCCq0CGS7uZIKl410QQ.text: Honestly, the place is a nice, cheap takeout option. But it won't blow you away. If you are from the States like me, this is almost your typical Chinese takeout restaurant, similar to Panda Express in terms of food. I don't know if I would quite call it authentic as it claims to be, at least certainly in the Chinese food aspect, but it was a serviceable meal for a college student such as myself. I will probably stop back to try some other dishes soon, but I am certainly not in the greatest hurry. This place is just decent.

EwtoTQ-lFkb3AbqXz1hWVw.text: Come to this place hungry, the portions are massive and a bargin for the price, most of the mains are all under a fiver, the drinks are a bit on the expensive side but it all balances out.Chicken curry is nice, service is quick and efficient, have been going here for about 7 or 8 years, love the place!

4m9TboVG8b9aAy_i5JAUvg.text: Ok if you go in expecting terrible service you are good- i ate here three times and the food is inexpensive and delicious. The portions are very large.

94LtvUooszQUJqcLbSxvHg.text: Everyone's on about how cheap and good this place is - like grubby azn street food (in the best kind of way) but idk whatchu talkin' bout, 'cause this place aint that. I remember a year ago I'd come here for the kuay teow and it was good! Better than at Hare & Tortoise. The portion was huge, they had a good assortment of fishcake, char siew (bbq pork) and prawns, and it was tasty. It never quite had the wok hei (that almost smoky flavour from a well-seasoned wok) but at least it checked all the other boxes.I had the kuay teow the other day and was terribly disappointed. It was all the same ingredients but it was so bland. It just tasted like meh, uninteresting chili. Just spicy. Nothing else. And spicy because they knew that if it wasn't, people'd be like, uh this is just brown noodles that tastes like nothing?? And then there was the special fried rice. John H. I don't want to hate on you but I ordered it after seeing your review and THIS IS NOT LEGIT. AT ALL. £3.80? Pretty darn good, you'd think. Except when it's soggy rice that really doesn't taste of anything. The prawns tasted like water, totally unseasoned, and I'm pretty sure they were just defrosted. I make way better fried rice. And I'd charge you less than £3.80 too. It isn't that difficult to throw in some soy sauce, or even a pinch of MSG - you're a cheap chinese restaurant, you're allowed to do that yknow.On a slightly better note, I suppose the laksa is passable. It's nothing like proper laksa (again, Hare & Tortoise does a better job. Or if you want something even better, buy the Prima Taste packets from chinatown. That stuff's legit.) But at least this dish actually tastes of something and will keep you full. The fried tofu bits are pretty nomz.But really, if you want good, fast, and cheap chinese food at a place with limited service, go to Wong Kei in chinatown instead.

photos.caption: Photo of Chop Chop Noodle Bar - London, United Kingdom. Laksa

p1utG4cVC6ptIBaOxunK2w.text: When I was a student, I used to teach "English conversation classes" to a couple of lawyers in Japan. These weren't really classes...I would basically head to their office to chat in English for a couple of hours, then they would pay me ¥7000 (just under £50.) It was probably the easiest, most enjoyable part time job I have ever had!Anyway, one of these Japanese lawyers introduced me to the concept of "dirty but gooood" places to eat. Quite often we would go and eat in Osaka after the class...sometimes it would be to posh, gourmet restaurants, but we also headed off to small, shack-like, dirty-looking but really tasty eateries in the back streets of Umeda. When I discussed this with a Chinese friend back in London, he said he thought Chop Chop should count as a "dirty but gooood" restaurant, so of course I went to try it with high expectations.*sigh*I'm afraid I didn't agree with my friend. Chop Chop certainly has the "dirty" part of the description, but I can't describe it as "gooood." However, it IS cheap as chips, and was hugely popular with (manly male) students when I was at University. I suppose it is a Kings Cross institution as it has been there for sooo long! I went back in December with another friend who raves about this place. The waiter got our order wrong...but the food isn't bad considering the huge portions for the teeny price.If you need a summary without all my waffling on:  * Rude staff* Really cheap food* Huge portions* Best when you're inebriated

2Yhj2pAoK5Mu88vO6QlQ9w.text: Looking for an inexpensive but delicious meal, I Yelped and found Chop Chop Noodle Bar, which is across Euston Road from the King's Cross Underground Station. It's a small storefront, so just look for "left luggage" and it's directly across the street!Unlike many UK restaurants, your order is taken right at the table. A laminated menu with the list of options, including drinks, and a slip of paper to make your indications. All the food is prepared to order and I ws disappointed to not be able to see into the kitchen.However, when it arrived it was yummy! I went with the Singapore Laksa, which is a yellow curry coconut sauce with noodles, shrimp, sliced potatoes and tofu puffs. Absolutely delicious in a massive bowl, it was really warming on a cold day. Really inexpensive, even with a small bottle of Perrier, my meal was £6 (~$10). They also seem to serve the usual Asian stuff too - I saw tables with fried rice and other noodle dishes.Tight seating, but that was okay with me. I would absolutely return!

photos.caption: Photo of Chop Chop Noodle Bar - London, United Kingdom. Menu
Photo of Chop Chop Noodle Bar - London, United Kingdom. Singapore Laksa (oops, I ate half of it before taking the pic)
Photo of Chop Chop Noodle Bar - London, United Kingdom. It's across from the Left Luggage

5vfJw7F-SAV95IMu0Xbxxw.text: I only rate places that I like, but this is my first exception. I am disgusted. First of all, I was served the wrong dish.When they corrected it, the vegetable soup was literally hot water with a lot of hastily chopped vegetables inside. There was literally no flavour. My main course of vegetable noodles was glue-like and had copious amounts of oil.I suppose you get what you pay for - including poor service. I would not recommend.

Bf1HWGEq_bn90QauxVKtsw.text: We went there as it was the only Chinese restaurant in the area. We were starving and wanted a quick meal. Food was awful and service was mediocre. They charge additional for chilli sauces. The food were cold although portions were big. Obviously quantity over quality here. Cash only. Most dishes are priced in the region of £5. I would rather go to a fast food restaurant than to eat here again.
